Posts.Content: I lost a few of my toe nails. My fingernails went really dry and started peeling away so I cut them as short as i could nd just kept filing off the flaking bits.  I also made sure I wore washing up gloves every time and rubbed nail oil in at least 3 or 4 times every day.  I had my last chemo in March and my nails are slowly improving.   I wore dark nail varnish for the first few months of chemo but I think it made it worse, your nails need to breath and wearing nail varnish constantly is never going to help the condition of your nail bed.

Posts.Content: Bedford, I can't offer you any advice but thank you for posting this,  your situation is very similar to mine.  I'm a H cup band size 38.  I'm due to have a masectomy on my left side on the 11 April followed by radiotherapy a few weeks later.  I'll let you know how I get on as we'll only be a week apart.   My oncologist told me it'll probably be around this time next year before I can have a reconstruction and I need to loose weight before the will do it. I'm more worried about the emotional side of loosing my breast than I am about the surgery, I'm 45 and not ready to give up on my looks.  Before all this I'd have said my boob were my best feature.

Posts.Content: Hi - Im 6 month post chemo and aged 46.  BC (before cancer) I was pretty active, since I can barely get up the stairs at home, some days I have to pull myself upstairs using the handrail or crawl on all fours, my bones seem to set in position if I've been sitting for a while, its horrible and embarrasing sometimes as I work in an office.   I asked my ONC about it and he said its most likely the chemo but it could also be the tamoxifan, apparently it should improve with time and is all to be expected.
Posts.Title: 1 yr post chemo is this normal?

Posts.Content: Your right about having to grieve for the loss of my breast, I've know this was coming since October and I've been dreading it so when I first had the op I think I was just relieved it was over and done with, now the reality has hit me hard.   Jane - the vests are a great idea, I'm going to order a couple.  Did you get the shape wear ones or just normal vests? I suspect the shape wear vests may be too tight to be comfortable?  I understand the reasoning behind waiting for the revonstruction as I still need to have radiotherapy but it seems so cruel and I look so disfigured.
Posts.Title: had left sided masectomy last week, so sad today

Posts.Content: Myleft sided masectomy was a week today and I thought I was coping OK but today I've just felt like crying all say.  I'm a double H on the right side and nothing on the left and it's just so obvious.  I can't even wear my bra because it's just too painful under my arm, so I can't wear my softie.  I dont have the confidence to leave the house anymore,, even with my coat on you can see how lopsided I am.  I was going to take my dog to the park today but I chickened out, loosing my hair to the chemo and facing the stares of strangers are bad enough but this is even worse, my surgeon has told me I won't be able to have a reconstruction for at least a year, how on earth am I going to manage.   Please tell me it gets better.
Posts.Title: had left sided masectomy last week, so sad today

Posts.Content: Get - that is so good to hear, my mum keeps telling me it's early days and I need to give it more time.   The pain isnt too bad, isometimes t hurts a lot when i move and I've been having a bit of nerve pain but at least its not constant and it's not as bad as I expected, It just feels tight almost like a rubberband is stretched across me and I'm having problems lifting my arm up high.  It's the emotional side I'm struggling with.  I didn't know the anesthetic could make you emotional maybe in a few more days I'll feel a bit calmer.
Posts.Title: had left sided masectomy last week, so sad today

Posts.Content: Sharkay - you sound so much like I felt 6 months ago.  Please don't bottle up your feelings it'll only make you feel worse, do you have anyone you can be honest with?  I have a friend at work who has been amazing and just listened whilst I ranted and cried and my BC nurse has been brilliant too.   In answer to my own question it does get easier, it's a month on from the masectomy now and the pain is much, much better, I hardly notice it most of the time.  For any other larger ladies Asda post surgery bras actually fit me so at least I can go out now without looking lopsided and that has helped me get some confidence back.

Posts.Content: Thanks for all the replies.  I wasn't offered a skin sparing masectomy, I did ask but the surgeon said this was my only option.   He described my cancer effected breast as a bad breast and said the cancer would be very likely to come back unless I have a masectomy.  Ive cried a hell of a lot the last few days but  i think i do feel a bit calmer today.  I wish I could just get the op over and done with now, the count down really is torture.   On the practical side how painful is it going to be to put on say a t-shirt.  I really don't wear button-up clothes and don't want to buy things just for the recovery unless I really have to.  I have a dressing gown which ties at the front so could maybe wear that with pj bottoms for a couple of days.  The journey home from the hospital I could just put my coat on over my bra.
